title: US soccer fan quits her job to spend the year watching football
text:
Quitting the 9 to 5 to dedicate your life to watching sport sounds like the stuff of idle daydreams, but for one football-obsessed fan, it's become a reality.

Jessica Malone, from Denver, decided to call full-time on her job at an environmental consultancy firm in Colorado, a post she'd been in for ten years, to follow the beautiful game across the globe.

Malone, 33, has spent the last six months doing exactly that, watching as much football - and some tennis - as possible at famous stadiums around the world including in Europe, South and Central America - ending her adventure on Wednesday night at La Bombonera in Buenos Aires, Argentina.

On the football trail: Jessica Malone, 33, from the US, left her job at an environmental consultancy firm earlier this year and flew to Madrid in March to begin her dream of taking a sabbatical dedicated entirely to watching sport (Pictured watching the US women's national team in action in Reims during the World Cup)

Jessica has traversed three continents and seen 44 matches in 13 countries since April including watching a game at Rio de Janeiro's famous Maracanã stadium

Manchester's Theatre of Dreams, aka Old Trafford, has also see Jessica pay a visit as she watched the Leicester City vs Manchester United match in September

The Newcastle United fan has so far clocked up 44 stadiums - in 13 countries - seeing top flight women and men's matches and visiting such hallowed grounds as Manchester United's Theatre of Dreams and Barcelona's Nou Camp.

Among the UK grounds Malone has visited, she's taken seats at Wembley, Stamford Bridge, Anfield and the Etihad Stadium. A highlight, she says, was watching her team, Newcastle United, beat Manchester United earlier in the season at St James Park on Tyneside.

Staying modestly, often in hostels, Malone, who says she'll go back to work next month, says she's had the time of her life planning her travels purely around soccer matches.

The prospect of seeing Barcelona star Lionel Messi, one of the game's greatest ever players, set Jessica on her football-watching journey

A follower of the mens and womens games, the soccer fan watching the Manchester derby at Manchester's Etihad stadium

Have passport, will watch football: the journey for Jessica began in Madrid six months ago

She told the BBC: 'I didn't have a place to live so when I quit I hadn't put all my travel plans together but just knew I had to leave and figure it out later.

She added: 'I thought about the number one thing I wanted to do and that was seeing Lionel Messi play.

'I had certain stadiums and teams in mind that I thought, if I don't see them play during this time in my life, when will I do it?'

Malone says she's now blown the final whistle on her adventure after watching River Plate and Boca Juniors play at the historic La Bombonera stadium in Buenos Aires, Argentina on Wednesday night.
description: US soccer fan Jessica Malone, from Denver, has seen 44 matches in 13 countries across three continents in the last six months including Manchester's Old Trafford and Wembley Stadium.
